row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.
From and after October 1st the through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said every Monday at 5 p.m.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de uxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles. £ 19.4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S. "Omrah" will leave Suez about November 2 .
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.

R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8

Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, October 13th, to be followed by S.S. Menephthah.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo.
For particulars apply R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
Fare (home.) £10 Passengers returning by end October allowed 20% off outward fare (£14).
S.S. AMARAPOORA 6600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about October 6 for Dover.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about October 11 for Dover.
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about October 25 for Dover.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).

div.head: Icilma
div.p: MOT 'ARABE SIGNIFIANT "COULE L EAU"

Tolima Fluor Cream est la seule crème qui ne contient'ni de la grate ni de l'huile. Discrètement parfumée cette crème dettoie la peau animirrble ment, donne une blancheur de perle, et communique la vitalité aux timus, l'elasticité aux muscles, et une fraicheur délicieuse par toute la peau. Ses vertus uniques derivent d'une au minéralenaturelle,
sinni on peut bien l'appeler
Creme naturelle

et la peau n'a besoin qua de cette cráme pour s'am. surer la vitalité nécessaire pour resister aux rayons du soleil, a la chaleur, an froidet aux effets désastreux des eaux saumitres, pour empêcher et guérir les | irritations et les vices du sang surchaufle, et pour Conserver la jeunes fraiche et sans les rides, qui arrivent si vite dans les pays chauda
L'emploi de cette créme éloigne besucoup les insectos et les mous táques et soulage immédiatement de leurs piqûres. Dépòt pour l'Egypte : J. Naogregor, Pharmacien
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimich, Luxor.
Iollma Co., Ltd, 5 Rue de la Palx, Parle.

div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh – most charming Seaside Residence in Egypt
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais" tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort. Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
Telegraphic Address: BEAURIVAGE, Ramleh. – Telephone: 186, Ramleh. G. & M. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

REMARKS.
There is no change in the weather conditions. The early morning was bright and clear with a light northerly breeze and steady barometer.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
OBSERVATIONS BY SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: THE PLANETS
div.p: Mercury appears as an evening star about the middle of the month.
Venus is an evening star.
Mars is visible for about two hours before sunrise. Jupiter risca shortly before midnight.
Saturn is visible nearly all night except towards the end of the month, when it sets at 1.30 am.
The chief constellations in the South at 9p.m. are Perasus (Chief star Merkab) bear the Zenith, Aquarius about 600 and Capricornus about 400, above the horizon.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

The Egyptian Gazette
THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Manager . . R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1906.

div.head: The Sultan's Successor
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of the "Tribune" in a recent letter to our contemporary concerning the much discussed question of the succession to the throne of Turkey writes as follows:—For some weeks there have mysterious rumours of the possibility of an attempt to change the succession to the Turkish throre. The most persistent is that it is the desire of Abdul Hamid to appoint his third son, Prince Burhan-ed-din, as his successor, and for this purpose to obtain the consent of the Sheik-ul Islam and of the Ambassadors of the Great Powers. It is even added that Abdul Hamid is thinking of abdicating in favour of this prince. The rumoured step would be an exceedingly grave one. It is probable that any attempt to make such a change without the consent of the ulema class, of whom the Sheik. al-Islam is the head, would fail, and might simply plange the country into revolution. It is further rumoured that the Sheik-ul-Islam has seen sounded, and that he has declared that such a change could never be sanctioned. This, however, I do not believe. Rumour further says that the German Emperor has | been asked for his counsel, and that the sudden return here, & week ago, of the German Ambassador is in connection with this question. While fully admitting that we are dealing only with rumours, these are so persistent and definite as to suggest that they have a basis of truth, and the questions raised by them become interesting and important.

The Moslem law of succession to a royal throne is based upon long usage, and enacts that the heir is the oldest male in the Royal for Imperial family. A simple illustration is furnished by the recent history of Egypt. When Mehmet Ali became, by Imperial firman and the recognition of Europe, Khedive of Egypt, the Sultan issued a firman in 1846 by which the succession was to be regulated] in the Moslem fashion--that is, the heir was always to be the eldest male descended from Mehmet Ali. The rule was strictly followed till the time of Ismail. On the death of Ismail the legal heir to the Khedival throne should have been Prince Halim, the youngest son of Mehmet Ali. But Ismail, in 1866, by means of very heavy payments, had induced Abdul Aziz, the Sultan of Turkey (who was deposed, and 'suicided" in 1876), to grant a new firman,, by which the succession was changed from the Moslem to the general European system of succession. When the representatives of England and France decided in 1879 to get rid of Ismail, they secretly, but unmistakably, gave him the opportunity to leave Egypt quietly, in which case the firman which he had obtained would be recognized, and his son allowed to reign in his stead. If he refused, Halim, the "de jure'' heir by Moslem law, would be placed on the throne. He agreed to go quietly. It was generally believed in this city that Abdul Aziz, in granting the firman changing the Egyptian succession, had the intention to change the succession to the Turkish throne. In such case Prince Yussuf Izzedin would have been the heir apparent, Tho revolution of 1876 put an end to any such design, and Murad, and then the present occupant, were girded with the Sword of Osman in conformity with the well-established rule. At the time, however, when the project of changing the Ottoman rule of succession was in the air, it was well

div.head: The Sultan's Successor Cont.
div.p: understood that the ulema clans were strongly opposed to it. They represent the conservative element of Islam ; and unless some very special circumstances should be brought forward, they would oppose a stout resistance to any change of the kind. The present heir to the throne is Reshad Effendi, the Sultan's brother. Both he and two elder brothers rank, on the ground of age, before the third son of the present Sultan. The supposed favourite of his Majesty for the succession is his third son, who is known to the Ambassadors as a bright and intelligent young man of about twenty years old. The question is mainly, though not exclusively, of course, one for the subjects of his Majesty, and especially for his Monlem | subjects. If the change is attempted, it will probably give rise to considerable trouble. -

The suggestion that Abdul Hamid would be willing to abdicate does not strike me as probable. Those who are in favour of his doing so speak disparagingly of Reshad Effendi; but there will be always a party strongly in his favour as representing the reign of Moslema law. There are precedents for passing over the heir, but the change has always been regarded as revolutionary.

Though, of course, the personality of the Sultan is for foreign States a matter of great importance, the representatives of such States will probably best consult the interests of their Governments, and certainly of Turkey, by having nothing to do with any proposal to change the succession. The fact that they or any of them favoured one candidate more than another would do much to make him un- popular with the Moslem population. The matter is primarily one for the Moslem people of Turkey, and for a foreign Govern. ment to pronounce an opinion one way or another would have the appearance of mixing in a Palace intrigue. If it be said that Turkey is more or less under European tutelage, and that the unanimous consent of Europe to s change of Moslem law would give it a sanction which would secure its general acceptance, my reply would be that unanimity on this subject is impossible, and to attempt to obtain it would occasion endless intrigue. It may be admitted that if the general consent of Europe could be obtained it might establish an important precedent. But if such consent has been applied for, and il, as is rumoured, negotiations are going on, it is because opposition is anticipated either by Turkey or by some foreign State. Even an attempt by the Concert of Europe would be denounced by the Moslem population as an interference by the giaours with their religious rights, | There is much to be said for and much against the alleged project. The generally expressed opinion is that certain Palace favourites, for their own purposes, are in its favour, and this would not recommend it to the Turkish population, and still less to Europeans. Indeed, in whatever way the expe. diency of a change in the law of succession may be regarded, its practical application will be dangerous. It will almost certainly lead to disturbances, and it ought to be a question for Turkish statesmen whether it is desirable to add to the many difficulties with which they have to deal a possible war of succession. For foreign States the question is at once tempting and dangerous. In the solution of the many questions in the Near East with which our country is concerned, it is difficult to see what advantage could be gained by entering upon it. Sir Edward Grey will probably conclude that his wisest course is to reserve speech or action, and take up the poste tion that Great Britain will stand aloof, and neither approve nor disapprove any action of the kind which the Palace advisers may choose to take.

div.head: By Appointment to
His Majesty The King.
BOVRIL
div.p: A 1/4-lb. bottle of Bovril yields 10 to 11 cups of a highly nutritious and stimulating beverage.

div.head: THE IMMODERATE PRESS
div.p: NOT ADMITTED TO SUDAN.

"Al Minbar" states in its issue of yesterday that it has received an official communication announcing that the journal will not be admitted into the Sadun. We can only express approval at the action of the Sudan Government in view of the immoderation with which to "Al Minbar" discusses political question relating to the occupying Power. The organa of the nationalist party have assumed the foolish course of indulging in mere tirade against the advisers of the Khedive, and by such bring upon themselves the possibility of a perfectly justifiable suppression. We are rather inclined to hope that the prohibition of such intemperate journals in the Sudan is an augury of the application of a censorship over the Press of Egypt. It is exceedingly regrettable that there should be cause to seriously consider such an innovation, but a certain section, which is not constituted by our vernacular contemporaries alone, bas become so seditious that we should feel ourselves obliged to support the Government in any means which they might deem necessary to check the violent and harmful declamations of unreasoning journaliste. Let such take a lesson from the suppression of "Al Minbar" in the Sudan, and learn that their turbulence may preclude them from the liberty which moderation would ansare and from the consideration of serious men.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Two new plague patients were admitted to hospital at Suez yesterday and one patient was discharged.

div.head: Anglout Ophthalmic Hospital.
div.p: The new oph.halmio hospital at Assiout war formally opened yesterday in the presence of pr
the moudir of the province.

div.head: Malouan Observatory.
div.p: The observatory will be open to the public on the 11th inst, on which occasion the Survey Department will be "at home."
Military Exemption.
The military exemption tax between January and August 31, 1906, realized L.E.164,900 as against L.E. 116,920 for the same period last year.

div.head: St Andrew's Church, Alexandria.
div.p: The sacrament of the Lord's Supper will be w celebrated on Sunday morning at the close of
the morning service. Friends and visitors are cordially invited.

div.head: The Pilgrimage.
div.p: Two days ago, 150 Turkish pilgrims arrived at [illegible] where they passed a couple of days and they have now proceeded to Suez to embark for the Hedjaz.

div.head: Law School Graduates.
div.p: By ranetiori of the Ministry of Justice, a number of graduates of the Khedivial Law School have been appointed "substituto du parquet" at the native courts.

div.head: European Police for Egypt.
div.p: Provision has been made in the budget of the Ministry of the Interior for 1907 for the European police who are to be attached to the forces at Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: Cairo Circulating Library.
div.p: On and after Monday, 8th October, the Cairo Circulating Library will be open at the usual winter hours, viz. from 10.20 a.m. to midday and from 4.30 to 6 p.m. of each day except Sunday.

div.head: Comptoir National d'Escompte
div.p: The Cairo branch of the Comptoir National d'Escompte, Paris, to be inaugurated on the 15th inst., will be temporarily housed in the Maison Manusardi. Emad el Dio Avenne, near the Hotel d'Angleterre.

div.head: National University.
div.p: The subscription towards the foundation of a National University has reached LE. 2,100.1. It is feared in some quarters that this scheme of a National University will share the same fate as that drawn up by several Khedivial princes and Egyptian notables at the time of the Mohamed Ali centenary.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On October 3, 6 vessels, 2 northward and 4; southward bound, transited the Canal and paid Fr. 177,712 50 for transit and passenger toll. Of these vessels, 3 were British, 2 German and Austrian. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 639,119.92, paid by 25 vessels, of which 9 were northward and 16 southward bound.

div.head: Slave Trade.
div.p: Mohamed Naeser, the notorious slave dealer, has at last been caught, after having eluded the vigilance of be authorities for eight years. Mohamel, who is the head of the El Parayat | tribe, is famous for the pitobed battle he fought with the police on September 28, 1905, where | ten of his band were arrested and condemned to 15 years' hard labor. Lately the band were surprized with 12 slaves, whom the patrol, however, were unable to liberate, owing to the resistance shown by the Bedonin.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: NEW AGENT FOR CAIRO.
div.p: ROME, October 4.

Signor Nerazzini, Italian Consul General at Shanghai, has been appointed Minister at Tangier, and Cav. Malmusi transferred to Cairo. Marquis Salvago Raggi has been transferred to Zanzibar. Signor L. Meroatelli has been appointed Consul General at Calcutta. SIgnor Medana, Consul General at Tripoli, has been transferred to Teheran. Signor A. Monaco, Consul General at Seoul, has been transferred to Shanghai. (Reuter)
Rome, October 4.
M. Malmasi, Minister at Morocco, has been appointed Minister at Cairo, vice the Marquis Salvago-Raggi, who is appointed Consul General at Zanzibar and Governor of Benadir. (H.)

The successor to the Marquis Salvago-Raggi at Cairo, Signor Giulio Malmusi, was born at Parma on the 15th April, 1841, and entered the Foreign Office at Rome on the 14th January, 1861. In the following year he was Appointed a Vice-Consul of the third class an 11 proceeded to Barcelona. He was advanced to the second class in 1865. He has been Vice-Consul at Gibraltar, Bona, and Trebizond. In 1872 he became a Vice-Consul of the first class and a Chevalier of the Crown of Italy two years afterwards. He went to Cairo as Consul in 1874 and to Alexandria in 1877, whence he was transferred to Phillipopolis in 1879. He became Agent and Consul General at Tonia in 1884 and subsequently held the Consul. Generalship at Liverpool and Trieste and was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary at Tangiers in 1595. In 1999 he was nominated Consul-General of the First Class.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: This morning, the Khedive came from Montazah to Ras El Tin Palace, and at noon proceded to the Ghamrawi mosque in the Customs quarter, where his Highness attended prayer.

div.head: SIR VINCENT CORBETT.
div.p: Quidnuncs in Cairo are busy finding a post in the diplomatic service for Sir Vinoent Corbett, owing to the romours afloat as to the Financial Adviser leaving the service of the Egyptian Government in order to take a position under the Foreign Office. Last week they had discovered a high position for him in the Legation at Brussels; the week before it was Vienna !

div.head: THE LABBAN AFFAIR.
div.p: POLICEMEN NOT GUILTY.
The Gouvernorat has received an official communication from the Parquet notifying! that Onbashi Mohamed Taha and shawish Ibrahim Abd-el-Aal, who were obarged with
having caused the death of Osman Ahmed - have been acquitted as not guilty and ordered to resume their duties.
The following in a summary of the contents of the document sent by the Parquet Gépét Cairo, to the Chef da Parquet of Alexandru in regard to the affair:

Having carefully examined the official papers 1 of inquiry held by the Alexandrian Parquet; and the decision of the Council of Discipline held at the Alexandria Government, regarding the death of Osman Ahmed, we find that the policemen Mohamed Taha and Ibrahim Abdel Aal are quite blameless on the ground that medical reports show that the death of the deceased was due to internal disease. The trial of the accused held by the Council of Discipline contains no evidence to incriminate the onbashi and shawish, and, moreover, the two witnesses being of the deceased's relatives, who prepared the charge against the policemen, their evidence can not be considered and furthermore the supposition that the policemen treated the man with some cruelty in the course of their duties affords, insufficient ground to incriminate them.

div.head: THE CENSUS OF EGYPT.
div.p: The preparations for taking the census of Egypt have already begun. Mr. Lewis, whose services have been engaged for taking the census by the Egyptian Government on account of his great experience in similar work in India, arrived at Alexandria yesterday, and paid a visit to the Alexandria Municipality in order to obtain some preliminary information on the subject of his new duties.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: The following visitors are staying at the Windsor Hotel. Alexandria : Lady Watte, Mies Bill, Mr. Bill, J. Whitworth, Mr. J Addie, Mr. Jullien, Mr. J. Kerr Mr. and Mia Berzeant, Mr. W. Sergeant, Mme la Comtesse Pignol and a maid. Mr. Kyan, Mr, van Pring, Mr. Wooley, Dr. Go'dchild, Mr. Wilkie, Dr. Cadman, Mr. Bejen, Mr. Ar drevos, Mr. Pircher, Mr. Schrei

Ch. Reymond, Mr. Palmer, Mr. Oeska, Dr. Aders, Mr. A. Rockner, Mr. Frank, Mr. Davies, Mr. Totbill, Mr. Negrir, Wr. Wilking, Mr. and Mrs. Cottan, Miss Cottar Mr. Dr. nt J. Goldsicb, Mr. Page, Mr. J. Coben, Mr. ra Schaat, Mr. G. Halse, Mr. Harris, Mr. Davidson. Mr. Calender.

div.head: THE SINAITIC BOUNDARY.
div.p: MR. KEELING IN DANGER.
Owen Rey and Fakhry Pasha are on their way to Akaba from Rafah, superintending en

route the erection of boundary pillars on each side of the frontier, at intervals of one mile. We understand that on their arrival at Akaba they will return by way of fort Nakhl on the way to Suez, from whence they will proceed direct to Cairo. We are assured that the relations between the Anglo Egyptian and Ottoman commissioners were extremely friendly. On the other hand, Mr. Keeling, of the Barvey Department, who was attached to the Commission, had a narrow escape between Akaba and Kuseima, at the hands of a raiding party of Bedouins, who had crossed the frontier in to attack one of the Bedouin tribes under Egyptian protection. As Mr. Kooling's guide belonged to the latter tribe his position might have proved very dangerous, but the Bedouins fortunately did not press their enquiries too close by Mr. Keeling's guide succeeded in persuading the leaders of the raiding party that he had no connection whatever with their enemies.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL
div.p: THB PROPOSED BANQUET.
Our Nationalist confrères are making the best of their time before Moustapha Pasha Kamel returns. "Al Moayad" criticises the Pasha's letter to Farid Bey as insincere.

Our confrère remarks : "He still considera bia enemies and his critica as opponents of true patriotism, enemies of all honest devotion to their country. He is modest-- he only hopes that the great gift of a University will be offered to Egypt in his name. We suppose he intends to lay the foundation stone himself."

“Al Watan", the well-known Coptic organ, remarks a propos of the Pasha's lotter to Farid Bey : --"Mastapha Pasha Kamel is far too modest in his assertion that he has done nothing worth repeating. He forgets or pretends to forget that he has sown the seeds of discord between Moslem and Copt, between Egyptian and Syrian ; that he bas declared England to be the deadly foe of Islam; that he taught Moslem to hate Christian, has brought England's anger upon us, has created that state of excitement among us which was described as fanaticism in the English Parliament and that he is the cause of all measuras taken or to be taken by England to close her grip on the land and responsible for the very unflattering opinion the English have formed of us."
"Al Mokattım” learns from a correspondent the details of the moon at the banquet which I will be given to Moustapha Pasha at the Grand Continental hotel.
Meat Soup
Turkey
Cakes
Bamia
Pastry with cream
Vine leaves stuffed with minced meat
Beklawa
Grilled meat
Turkish Delight
Salade
Omel fijfil (Bean soup with pepper)
Rice,

The writer adds: I hope that all who have found in patriotism a source of profit and an occasion for good cheer will not love this. superb occasion of regaling themselves at their), ease on dishes which are truly national.
The "Journal du Caire” remarks :--
D'une mentalité assez vulgaire, d'une intelligenoe tout-à-fait ordinaire, d'ope sensibilité médiocre, il tomba dans le "ridicale". Co D'est: | pas à vingt cinq ans, quand on ignore encore
la vie et qu'on n'a rien d'on apôtre, qu'on pgat. - prétendre goider la "conscienos" d'ane nation. I.

A demi éoloire (car il n'a qu'une demi-instroo tion, et il est vraiment un "primsiro") il se orat assez poissant pour entrainer le pays à sa suite et assez habile poor éviter tous les obstacles. Il n'était en réalité qoe naïf. Je your penser que jusque-la il fot sincère. Mais à partir de ce moment, à moins d'ôtre absolument atapide, il dot s'apercevoir que la latte était vaine et que l'Egypte jamais, ne pourrait se nationaliser. Alors nous avons découvert ce
que valaient, en réalité, ses grandes revendi|cations, son grand patriotisme et son grand

désintéressement | Son devoir ent été de sacrifier ses ideas chimériques et à défaut de la “nationalisation" impossible, il devait accepter la domion 1: tion anglaire qui a procuro du moins à son paya la véritable liberté, la sécurité, et qui al | mis fin à la tyrannią et à l'esclavage. Il ent| Ida a'efforcer -cola s'est fait en Algérie, cepen
dant-d'amortir les hearts des deax Ames * étrangères, de créer ane sympathie effective. |
on lien entre les deux nations. Mis quoi ! Son 10le edt été trop humble et il rêvait de
destinde plaa brillanto. Alors, avec son valgaire | d tempérament d'opposition, il s'est tourné

vers la Tarqnie. Désorm uis il devenait musal man avant d'être égyptien. La vanité l'aveu. glait, il perdait peu à pou, oe sing des réalités Jaana lequel on n'est qu'un àbrouillon", on politicien imbésile, go bayard...
Il revendiquait la liberté de son pays et à la domination sage, libre et prévoyante d'une Ination earopéenne, il préférait la domination
fanatiqae, 18-illonne et bypoorite de la Tur. Iqnie.
Il se dissit patriote et il préparait la mort . de l'Egypte. Car la vie d'un peuplo n'est
Arissante qn0 Bour, on gonvernement éslairé T. et évolationniste. De la Turqnie rétrograde Jet pourrie s'étouffo dans un p1886 politique sana franchise et sana liberté.

div.head: BLUNT'S ANTI-NATIONALSIM
div.p: HIS BIASSED CRITICISMS.
A correspondent writes as follows

You published the day before yesterday a letter to the “Times" from the pen of Mr. Blant, who therein expresses has "onlooked for pleasure" at finding himself "once more attacked, after a silence of some twenty years” by his old adversary, Mr. Moberly Bell. One can fully understand Mr. Blant's delight at the advertisement which he has received from a journal than which none other in the world stands higher, and were it not impossible to disregard the aspersions by which he tries to vilify his mother-dation, the publicity which he has received would be regrettable. Righteous indignation rankles in th: best of every true Britisher at the calomnies which are cast upon his nation by distorted fasts emanating from one of the Empire's song. Were Mr. Blunt content to criticise his country in an equitable spirit, to endeavour to obtain true and unbiased accounts of the happenings in Egypt, and to moderate his acrimony, one might read lo with interest and seriously consider his I writing. But his obvious hatred for his country makes one feel that it is impossible to wage with him the war of pens with the feeling that he is an adversary worthy of the steel.

Mr. Blant's asseveration that the "Times" exaggerates his anti English attitude cannot be accepted, as, in the opinion of every right minded person, a man who is guilty of such misrepresentation of facts and hyperbolical statements to the detriment of his country, as it are contained in his writings, can only be pronounced an an'i nationalist. We are well aware that his interest in the affairs and people of Egypt is of the keenest, and on each a point we could heartily agree with him, but in making it his obvious aim to sully the Damer L of Great Britain in hør dealings with a country which she has spatched from the abyss of bankraptoy and slavery and raised almost to t the pinnsole of prosperity be estranges that lo sympatby which serions men could otherwise hold for him. There might be some slight excuse were Mr. Blunt ignorant of this country and its people, but he has passed a considerable It portion of twenty-five years in Egypt, during which time he has seriously studied the customs of the modern Egyptians, and he cannot have b failed to note the unwavering maroh of progrezat that the country has made under our guidance. 1. Indeed, one is driven to doubt the sincerity 1. of the land of Little Englanders whose cry of "British Injustice in Egypt” is now so prominent, especially in view of the fact that one of the most conspicuous of these has a full knowledge of the country from personal experience.

That Mr. Blunt's latest publication will receive credence in England is hardly likely, for, happily, the majority of the home Press have dealt with the regrettable incident of Danishwai in that equitable spirit which is still the prədominant characteristic of the Britisher, despite the attempts of a small declamatory party to persuade the world of the contrary. There is the danger, however, that it may, in conjunction with the impetuous orations of certain members of Parliament and vehement arterioles of a few journalists lead some to doubt the wisdom with which the representatives of Great Britain are directing the Government of Egypt, and, though there will speedily be convinced of the injaatios of such a consolation if they are to study the question more deeply, a certain amount of mischief may be caused. It is somewhat remarkable that Mr. Blant should play a prominent part in the endeavour of a few self-styled nationalists to foment the native to the verge of fanaticism, when he asserts such interest in their welfare, as he must surely realise that any forcible demonstration would be to the serious disadvantage of the people. The irrationality of Mr. Blunt and his fellow antinationaliste, in addition to filling us with contempt, draws upon us the contomely of foreign nations, who come to the not unnatural conclusion that the abundance of Anglophobe Britishers is an indication of the deterioration of our race. As the crow pounces with avidity upon carriou, so such men seize every opportunity to belittle their fellow countrymen in the eyes of other nations. England, alas, is being nauseated by an unparalleled wave of anti-British hysteria, which became epidemic at the commencement of the Boer war, and the sound of raucous voices pouring undeserved reproach upon men who are conscientiously and successfally striving to further the interests of countries which the first Power of the world has taken under her wing has become sufficiently common to constitute a peril to the Empire. It is deplorable that men of our own nationality endeavour to hide their utter lack of patriotism and a spurious cloak of humanitarianism, and
hold up to the world as martyrs semi-barbarians who have been guilty of an extraordinarily
brutal outrage. Such absolute anti-nationalism is incomprehensible, and the attempt of our Little-Englanders to drive their mother-country on to the rooks is worse than dastardly.

div.head: STEAMERS MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Tebe, of the Navigazone Generale Italiana, sailed from Messina at 2 p.m., yesterday, with 100 first and second class passengers, and is due here on Sunday.

div.p: Every Night
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
Alexandria
From 6 to 12 p.m.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah.

div.head: THE MONEY FAMINE.
div.p: GOVERNMENT TO THE RESCUE
The prevailing scarcity of gold has today been very considerably alleviated by the
prompt action of the Government in conjunction with the National Bank. Certain funds
which are not available in ordinary cases have been placed as a temporary measure by the

Government at the National Bank's disposal. The mere knowledge of this fact, combined with the ansidance given by the Bank to the market, has changed the aspect of affairs, and by financial ciroles have resumed their normal activity at this season of the year.

The thanks of the financial and mercantile community are due to the Egyptian Government for the ready way it took measures to meet a situation which was causing serious inconvenience not only in Alexandria, but also in Cairo and the interior.

It appears to be popularly believed that if a State Bank was in existence in Egypt, it would be able to prevent any similar crisis owing to its large reserve. But if each bank were established, it would in all probability find it advantageous to keep its reserve in London just as the other banks do, seeing that money can be obtained by telegram in six days. To keep a large reserve permanently in Egypt would involve loss of interest during the summer to a considerable extent. As was remarked yesterday, it has been suggested that the Government and the Caisse de la Dette are somewhat to be blamed for the existing stringency, and so much money gets looked upon its receipt in payment of taxes. But it would be as well to remind our readers that, in virtue of the Anglo-French Agreement of 1904, the receipts of the land tax are paid in to the Caisse de la Dette, which has no power to release these items, while the balance of the Government revenues are sufficient at this beginning of the year to meet the outgoings in the shape of ordinary expenditure. Consequently no blame for such a stringency can fall on the
Government. It is, on the contrary, the banks upon whom the responsibility falls in failing

to be prepared for such an extraordinary contingency by making proper provision. On the other hand we do not consider that the banker can be held to be so fall of foresight as to anticipate such unexampled prices at the opening of the cotton season. It will be remembered that temporary crises of this patare are by no means unprecedented in the commercial records of Alexandria, and all such crises have been invariably alleviated in all few days time by the arrival of money from London.

As the currency of Egypt is practicably in British sovereigns, it is very easy to remedy any stringency by merely wiring to London. If, however, the currency were partly Egyptian, it is quite possible that a most serious situation would arise under similar circumstances.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
Lady Valda Machell, the wife of the Adviser of the Ministry of the Interior, was delivered of a daughter still born, at St. James's Palace on the 25th ulto.

Mr. and Lady Valda Machell have been staying at St. James's Palace in the rooms which have been lent to them by Princess Victor Hohenlobe, who is herself at Frensham for the time being. We understand that Mr. Machell leaves London today to join the P. & 0. mail steamer Osiris at Brindisi, and is due here on Wednesday.
H.h. Aziz Pasha Izzst, under-secretary to the Ministry for Foreign affairs, arrived in Cairo on Wednesday evening on his return from Europe.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidki, Governor of Cairo, came down to Alexandria yesterday evening.
Dean Butcher has been staying at Wesson Jon Lake Walensee. We regret to hear that he

has been confined to his bed for some days. A sudden abnormal drop in the temperature brought on a rather severe bronobial attack, but we are glad to learn that the attack is yielding to treatment, and we hope that he will soon recover his strength.

Professor Gottschlich, sanitary inspector of Alexandria, has returned to Egypt from Europe and resumed his official duties. He has been attending the medical congress at Lisbon on behalf of the Alexandria Municipality.
Mr. James Wilson, of Newcastle University, has been appointed professor at the school of
arts and crafts at Boulac.

div.head: THE ISIS DISASTER.
div.p: MAILS ON SUNDAY.
We are informed by the bad office of the Postal Administration that the Brindisi mail
will arrive at Port Said at six o'clock tomorrow evening and that the Alexandria distribution

will commence at 8 a.m. on Sunday. It will be observed from the Reuter's telegram which we append that the Isis has been sufficiently repaired to be able to continue her voyage. Doubtless she will be accompanied by the Persis, which as we reported yesterday, went to her help on receipt of the bows at Port Baid, so that in the event of further break down every assistance will be at hand.
Among the passengers who, according to Reuter's despatch of the day before yesterday,
ran so great a risk of serious injury; were Mr. H. Ampinall, the popular secretary to the Torf
Clab, Cairo, and Mr. George Walker, of the firm of Messrs. Walker and Meimaracbi.
The weekly Brindisi mail will be made up at the G. P. O., Alexandria, on Sunday at
3.10 p.m. for ordinary correspondence. Registered letters must be posted one hour earlier.
ZANTE, October 4.
The Isis has left with passengers and mails for Port Ssid, where she is expected to arrive on Saturday. (Reuter)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to perrott-within a certain necessary limit free discussion.
OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,---It is a thousand pities that "A Mere Business Man" should have so mis-read the letter I wrote to you from the Fayoum a few days ago. I was then labouring under the impression that I was accusing one of your correspondents of snobbishness in speaking slightingly of the benefits of a Board School Education. I ventured to point out the superiority of a Board School Education to that of Public School and 'Varsity, and I spok, of the latter form of education as being possibly a misfortune. Will “A eore Business Man" do me the favoar of reading my letter once again and more carefully, and then informing me whence he infers that I consider that the British Commercial Community here has enjoyed a Board School education! No such insinuation was made, and moreover the benefits of a Board School Education were described as superior to those of a 'Varsity and Publio Bohool education. How the remarks in my letter could have been so distorted as to bring about a meaning contrary to that intended is hard to imagine. There seems to be considerable bitterness shown on the part of the unofficial correspondents in this controversy. Let them rest assured that this bitterness is in no way reciprocated, and that the greatest admiration, and respect for our commercial fellow countrymen here, who do so much to keep England’s name and reputation bright, are felt by all Anglo-Egyptian officials, not excluding
"CIVILIAN OFFICIAL."
Rosetta, October 4.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE ."

Sir,---The charge made against "five or six civilian officials” by your correspondent "Ex. Officio" appears to me to be an argument in favor of my original suggestion, that all Government officials or employés should wear the tarbush as a protection against being taken for members of the commercial community. Surely if the official clsdd adopted the suggestion made in my letter of the 19th September and, wore some distinguishing badge no such charge as that referred to above could be made against a community composed of gentlemen who are mostly University scholars, and who as such, I feel sure, would never disgrace themselves in the manner stated to have occurred in the small hours of the morning.--I am, etc.
ANOTHER RESIDENT OF OVER 80 YEARS'S STANDING.
Cairo, October 4.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir. — The ideal condition of existence in Cairo would be a community of Anglo-Egyptian officials, undisturbed by the presence of any commercial people of their own race. The British commercial man is doubtless a very well-meaning person in his way, but his presence introduces a certain jarring note and I fully sympathise with the attitude of French
and German officialdom, who in the so-called colonies of those nations do their best to

ensure a tranquil life by suppressing the commercial men of their own race by making their existence intolerable. However, for good or ill, such is not the policy of the British Government and at Cairo we should learn to tolerate them. We need not arouse their irritation by us patronising airs and should always rather adopt a condescending attitude to this class of human beings, but at the same time if they consider that their racial relationship to us affords them a special right to criticise, they should be taught to keep to their place. The best way of treating these people is to adopt an attitude of studied irony towards them. Sach treatment would prevent them from becoming familiar, as it appears to puzzle them.---I am, truly yours.
СANТАВ.
Cairo, October 4.
